output: Thank you Mr President. I welcome the approach described in the White Paper which highlights the causes of malnutrition and obesity and the resulting diseases.

Unfortunately, we fall foul of life sciences policy in Europe, regardless of whether we are discussing nutrient profiles, food labels or even in some parts of the White Paper, a very one-sided approach.
We try to solve the problems we have in Europe regarding product policy.
I believe that it is fundamentally wrong to assume that there are good and bad foods.
Many amendments show that there is no such thing.
There are only good and bad, or balanced and unbalanced, nutritional ways of eating.
That should be our approach.
The causes of bad eating habits are multifaceted.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on geography for help. The sentence means 'It will not lead us to our destination if we try to guide consumers through product labelling or even by banning advertising or regulations, or setting different value-added tax rates.'

Everything we do here - I do not want to take up too much time with the discussion on the regulation on product labelling - should be somewhat underpinned by the idea that what can we do to motivate consumers to think about their eating habits?
In my opinion, an ampel marking which suggests whether a product is good or bad is more likely to be a device for driving people away than an instrument for education and enlightenment.
I therefore wish for a more balanced approach and the realization that we cannot continue along this path with product policy alone.
The budget control has no new topics.
We are satisfied with the old ones and would also be content with progress on the old issues.
Five points first of all. Our urgent request for support for Romania and Bulgaria in building up the rule of law, the justice system and financial control.
We do not want to be in the same position we are in today in two years' time, which is why this point is very important to us.
The second point is the reliability declaration for the overall budget after the scaled-down control procedures under the involvement of national accounting institutes.
It would be nice if we could achieve decisive progress in the last six months, or at least agree on a common path forward.
As a budget controller, one would be modest.
The third point would be simplification.
We need to help our member states implement EU law more effectively at local level.
It shows that they are completely overwhelmed by large parts of EU law, which leads to high error rates.
The fourth point is foreign aid – here I would mainly like to refer to Kosovo and the issue of cooperation with the United Nations.
The budgetary control committee has been in Kosovo, and I would like to announce now that Kosovo will play a certain role in budgetary relief.
I believe that we have so far remained well below the possibilities of the European Union and that we urgently need to make progress in this area.
The fifth point would be improved cooperation between Member States in the fight against fraud.
We have homework here, mainly for the ladies and gentlemen of the Council.
In November, Parliament will vote on the legal basis and the regulation for anti-fraud measures, and then we must together consider how we can achieve better results in this field.
That was at least our common wish.
India and Europe need more and better contacts with each other at all levels, particularly also on the level of so-called normal people.
Business travelers, tourists, students, etc. A brief remark on this point - it also has significance for the Commission's legislative program that we discussed earlier.
In global aviation, we need good safety regulations - regulations that achieve something and not just mere band aids.
Therefore, it would be a sensible and really necessary measure to finally lift the absurd liquid restrictions and to come up with something better.
I voted in favor of the resolution because it clearly calls on the Russian government to respect human rights once and for all.
It is disappointing that expectations for democratic development for the people of this European dictatorship with questionable, yes, falsified parliamentary elections in September have not been met.
The same applies to the strategic suppression of the opposition as well as civil society.

At the same time, we have today called on the Council and the Commission to ease contacts between peoples and to intensify them, and to democratise the country by seriously considering the possibility of one.
Reducing visa fees for Ukrainian citizens when entering the Schengen area and thus preventing an increasing isolation of Ukraine and its citizens.
I wish to preserve the ghost of a statement I heard a few minutes ago, according to which foreigners would swamp our labour market.
Secondly, I would have preferred a clearer, more explicit report from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.
Trust in the social cohesion of the European Union can only be achieved if fundamental social rights are defined as European primary law.

We should send a stronger signal to the Council, the Commission, the Member States and the EUIH and not be satisfied with merely striving for a balance between fundamental rights and internal market freedoms and freedoms of movement.
We do not change anything. Social fundamental rights are just as important as freedom of movement and human rights, which must not be restricted by the freedoms of the internal market.
It is about defending and improving the European social model, and the time has come to introduce a social progress clause as a binding protocol to the existing EU treaties.
It is time to change the expellee directive so that wages and minimum standards requirements should not be limited as minimum requirements.
Thank you, Mr President. I would like to add my thanks to the rapporteur, Doris Pack, who has already been mentioned by many colleagues quite rightly.
We have someone with you who actually hopefully does not shed blood, but invests a lot of blood in this room.
I welcome you and those colleagues who have said the same that there has been some progress made, also in the area of police cooperation.
It is important so that actual life on site can also function in a reasonable manner.
We have to keep on reminding our partners in Belgrade and Pristina that they themselves have a lot to do, much more than has been done recently in some areas.
We must continuously encourage internal cooperation and willingness to work together within the EIB.
It will not do for everyone to try to go their own way.
The integration into regional cooperation in the Western Balkans is important.
The gap between the European Union and its citizens cannot remain as large as it has become.
We must ensure that it is minimized.
In this connection, the ombudsman has an important task, especially where and when he can do good.
It is also about calculating with the engagement and scale of the citizens' commissioner.
The English translation of the provided German speech is: 'We should not set expectations that no one can meet.'

On the other hand, it is also important that wherever malfunctions have occurred in the administration of European institutions, these are dealt with and, where possible, reasonable solutions are sought which will ensure and satisfy citizens.
The previous practice has shown that the ombudsman carries out this task seriously and well.
We can hope that this will continue to be the case and thank him and the rapporteur for their report.

Ist es wirklich schon so spät? 

Translation: 
Is it really that late already?
Ladies and Gentlemen, ten years after the implementation of the common currency, Europe finds itself in a serious crisis.
Banks breaking up each other or being supported with millions from the state budget? The insolvency breaks in and millions of people fear their jobs and their future.
But not only has the market failed, it seems that the prevailing politics is also unable to learn from its mistakes.
We hold the view that with such intermediate remarks you should not single yourself out in particular! We hold the view that grave mistakes were made in constructing the Economic and Monetary Union.

One such mistake is the structural inconsistency between money and fiscal policy. You cannot create a common currency without simultaneously harmonizing tax and expenditure policies at least in principle.
In the eurozone, economic imbalances have become much more pronounced.
What we need now is actually better coordination of economic policy and, above all, also of tax policy.
We need effective measures against tax evasion; besides, tax havens must be closed and capital movements finally brought under control.
The second serious mistake we see in the construction of the stability and growth pact is...

Who in times like these holds on to budget consolidation as unchangeable, obviously lives in another world! Nothing could be more fatal than to react to this economic crisis with public austerity programs now.
The Stability Pact has clearly failed.
It should be replaced by an integrated European strategy for solidarity and sustainable development.
In our view, there is a need for an investment strategy for the renewal of public infrastructure and the improvement of the situation of socially disadvantaged people in Europe.
A third mistake we see in the construction of the European Central Bank itself, which is not subject to democratic control and is solely committed to the objective of price stability.

We stand up for democratic control of the European Central Bank and also demand a correction of the monetary policy mandate of the ECB, so that in future growth and employment must at least be equally promoted with price stability.
The ongoing crisis also presents an opportunity for far-reaching reforms of the European monetary and financial architecture.
This chance should not be taken lightly.
In fact, the automotive industry is in crisis, and there are many reasons for this.
The financial crisis has once again exacerbated the crisis in this sector, and solutions are currently being worked on in the Member States.
The European automotive industry is a key industry.
Therefore, we need European solutions to tackle this crisis.
Most car manufacturers are now European structures.

And in order for car manufacturers to be able to invest in environmentally friendly technologies and make them affordable, they need public-private partnerships or cheap loans from the European Investment Bank.
But also the supply industry, which is very important to us, must not be forgotten in this regard.
Es ist gerade in der Zulieferindustrie, wo kleine und mittelständische Unternehmen sind, dass Arbeitsplätze geschaffen werden und Innovationen stattfinden.
But what can the European Union do to protect this key industry?
In the last plenary session, the President-in-Office made a proposal to protect key industries.
A good proposal, if you think about it consistently, is called a Volkswagen law for the entire European automotive industry.
This would certainly be a good instrument.
However, this protective instrument is currently being fought by the European Commission.
The European Commission will not change its stance on the automotive industry crisis despite the crisis.

Mr President, Mr President of the European Court of Auditors, Vice-President of the European Commission, ladies and gentlemen, it has indeed become tradition now to establish a budgetary framework for the coming year.
The speaker is saying that there can be no repeated certification of reliability in the relationship between expenditure at European level and management at national level.

I can recall conversations with the former President of the Accounting Court, Professor Friedmann, who once told me that it is simply impossible to provide a reliable audit certificate on God's structures.
Therefore, let us ponder together how this instrument can also be made more effective so that the goal of an 'unconditional declaration of reliability', if justified, can also be achieved.
We must naturally distinguish several things from each other.
Firstly, a budget that contains around 95% subsidies is much more prone to fraud than a national budget, a regional budget or a communal budget.

A subvention budget which will be managed essentially by the Member States, that is what we have been asked for in the new financial period because the criticism levelled at the last funding period was that it was too centralised.
The responsibility for the money must be assumed regionally and nationally.
I would like to briefly address a third topic area.
We also need to learn to distinguish between fraud and waste.
These are issues that are always thrown together.
I am also concerned when EU funds are used for things that are not necessarily necessary.
This was not fraud, it was waste.

Therefore, those who are responsible for the projects, especially in the field of structural policy, also have the responsibility to ensure that money is not wasted and that only projects which really add value to the region are supported.
Therefore, I think we should also consider converting parts of the structural policy into interest-free loans.
If we have to make payments to the Member States, then we should support what they really need. Thank you very much.
It is not difficult for me to align myself with this emerging self-pride of European decision-makers when it comes to dealing with the financial crisis.
Because if Europe were a functioning democracy, one would have to ask first and foremost about accountability for how all this came to be.
It is not true that we should deal with a tsunami when we have all the problems we currently face, as it is something man-made, not natural.
Despite all the regulatory zeal that this Union has demonstrated, one might ask why were not banks dealt with in a substantial manner, as they started to cross national borders?
Why was action not taken despite appropriate warnings when the derivatives slipped in?
I am well aware that your Nobel Peace Prize laureate, Joseph Stiglitz, has talked about all these points.
There was silence, there was a taboo.
The key to solving future problems lies in acknowledging our own mistakes.
Mr President, Mr Oettinger, ladies and gentlemen, my question relates to what you think about Iceland and Hungary introducing the euro as a second currency.
Do you believe that this could solve the problem of these two countries?
The second question is whether you believe it would be possible to introduce a risk premium for dividends that could then be used to strengthen banks' own capital.
My third question is, do you not believe that a reduction in value-added tax would support imports, especially from China and India?
It would not be reasonable not to consider tax reduction for our enterprises and our employees about paying investment bonuses and progressive writing off accordingly in the medium term.

The central point is that we should increase the amount of economic assets by a factor of ten, so that there will be no tax on windfall profits, but instead the money will stay in the companies, which will enable better wages to be paid.
The comprehensive report makes it clear how many human rights violations occur in the world on a daily basis.
It is particularly shocking sixty years after the declaration of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and it calls on us to redouble our efforts.
Also from this reason, I would like to support the establishment of the present subcommittee on human rights as the main committee.
Today we awarded the Sakharov Prize to Hu Jia, who in China is fighting for human rights and the environment.
However, as he was incarcerated, he was unable to personally take them over.
Sorry for China. And there will be a debate tomorrow about human rights violations in Russia.
In our relations with these two countries, we must attach greater importance not just to economic interests, but also above all to human rights.
We demand freedom for Hu Jia in China and freedom for Mikhail Khodorkovsky in Russia.

Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, distinguished Members of the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, as rapporteur for the Anti-Fraud Office, I make interesting experiences – namely those where everyone talks about fraud and no one does anything.
Or the experience that the Member States calculate their payments to the European Union with great precision but then, when they actually pay out this money, they tighten their belts.
And it even makes it easy for cheaters! For example, by making irregularities in the European Union not be reported until an average of thirty-six months have passed.
The European Parliament is not in agreement with this.
We want efficient fraud prevention that includes prevention.
We want the Member States to make combating fraud a topic and to discuss together the necessities and problems associated with it.
We want a greater interest of national justice authorities in the further investigation of OLAF results.
In the field of cromometrics, there can no longer be any room for unlawful practices as has been the case up until now.
We need an equality between European money and national money.
We want an independent office which has the necessary resources and legal bases to carry out its tasks.
We want an office that can work quietly and efficiently with the Member States.
Our position on the legal basis 1999/73 sees all these points in advance.
We aim to further develop this regulation as the core part of the anti-fraud office together with the Council.
We call on the Council to work on our position, we call on the Council to start negotiations on the further development of this regulation.
We want to solve the problems of OLAF.
Thank you to all the groups in this House for supporting this resolution, which we will vote on tomorrow.
I appeal to the French and Czech Presidencies to take up the ball that Parliament has thrown back into play.
We have also taken up solutions that were developed by the Council working group and incorporated them into our proposals.
We express our interest in reaching a swift conclusion on this regulation and assure you of our constructive willingness to engage in talks based on our proposals.
Consolidation of all OLAF legal bases as envisaged by the Council would mean another substantial time loss with uncertain outcomes.
OLAF will soon celebrate its tenth birthday.
Consolidation means another ten years without improved legal basis.
For this reason, we take anti-fraud very seriously.
We want to achieve as much as possible in cooperation with the Council.

Ladies and Gentlemen,
Thank you very much.
The English translation of the provided German speech is: 'Mr President, I would like to make a remark which my Austrian colleague, Mr Rübig, has already mentioned.'

We spend less than one percent of Europe's gross domestic product on Europe, and we want at the same time that more and more tasks for more and more Member States should be handled by the European Union.
This calculation cannot be allowed to go on; it is therefore also truly unbelievable that we have been driving a savings course for many years now, but not just in a frugal way.
The use of our money should not be primarily about taking it away from us again at the end of the year so that the finance ministers can put it back into their budgets.
We would have enough new tasks for which we should spend our money.
We also have tasks that we have not really budgeted for properly for years.
I believe that the information budget of the European Union should be significantly increased if we really want to connect European citizens to Europe.
There is a lot that Europe could do in terms of student and trainee exchanges.
The justice sector is also advancing into areas that have traditionally been the preserve of the state.
It corresponds to the changed life situations of people in our Union.
However, as has been repeatedly emphasized, integration must not go too far in respect to traditionally grown ones, and especially must not interfere with functioning structures there.
Not everything can be achieved through one single list.
Public records and public record keepers differ significantly across many Member States.
In Austria, but not only there, the notary has a long tradition as a public record office with a high level of security and trustworthiness.
This should not be played with unnecessarily just because such professional groups do not exist elsewhere.
Therefore, yes to integration and mutual opening up, but with a view to balance.
Plant protection products are and remain essential inputs for agriculture.
Farmers need a minimum selection of plant protection products because it concerns the protection of domestic culture landscapes, high-quality nutrition, and resource protection.
We discuss chemicals far too often on an irrational level.
In order to achieve sensible results, we must think and act rationally.
The impacts of the initial position of the parliament would have been fatal: A broad ban on plant protection products, resulting in less crop production and ultimately higher food prices.
Therefore, I am pleased that in the trialogue negotiations, an acceptable compromise was found.
It is commendable that we have retained the three zones regulation, albeit with considerable exceptions for Member States.

A bold step towards a consistent internal market solution would look very different at this point in time! In addition to acceptable compromises, we should not preemptively define endocrine active substances, but actually give the EU Commission four years to come up with a scientifically based definition.
Otherwise, we would be overstepping the principle of prior examination at this point in time.
And lastly, I find it regrettable that we were unable to agree on a follow-up assessment regarding the current agreement reached. Thank you again.
The President of this House has taken a massive interest in opinion-giving when it last occurred during a visit by a head of government or state.
It was about an issue that he himself considered important, namely the Treaty of Lisbon.
If the President, who has been democratically elected as the head of state, speaks today and his speech is massively interrupted or disturbed, does he raise his voice?
Do you know what it is?
This is not democracy, this is anarchy, and I demand that corresponding measures be taken.
Children and politics rarely go so far apart in interests as they do today.
In Europe, the topic of children is at the top of everyone's agenda.
For politicians, child care issues are often subsumed under 'further education' as we can see here once again.
I do not know any country where there is a separate child ministry! Even in the Commission, there is no own representative for the interests of our youngest citizens.
In parliament, the topic of children is spread across all committees.
Therefore, I would like to draw the Commission's attention at this point in particular to the fact that it has been occupied with child care institutions and Barcelona objectives today.
In our parliamentary working group on quality of childhood, we have established the following: Our children are growing up in a very complex world.
The future of a person who is a child here, now and today is completely uncertain.
A child of today can climb all the way up on the social ladder or fall far down.
It can stay in its own cultural circle or seek a new one.
It can follow a similar life path as its parents or take an entirely different turn.
It is possible for someone to marry someone from another gender or their own gender.
Everything was more than 50 years ago when we took the European Union out of the darkness. It was completely different.
The diversity that characterizes us Europeans has become an essential factor in the lives of children.
The concept of diversity must therefore find its way into pedagogy, child care and teaching.
This is currently being considered much too little.
The children's care institutions and schools in Europe are breaking down with the challenge of integration.
In matters of integration, we need to press the reset button and start again.
Let's approach this topic once again in a completely unbiased manner according to the motto 'Unity through Diversity'.

And above all, I would like to urge all my future European Parliament colleagues not just to campaign for gender mainstreaming, but also to fight for children mainstreaming. Go right now, in the midst of the global financial crisis, because we cannot leave our children with an unbearable burden of debt. Thank you very much.
I want to keep it short.
Thank you very much for these constructive debate contributions that I have heard here.
Firstly, I would like to express my gratitude to the Commissioner for not fundamentally rejecting the concept of minimum requirements for the security network.
This proposal is not a piece of nonsense, and it is also not a bureaucratic monster.
It is a problem-solving instrument which we should seize the opportunity to use.
Therefore, I would like to appeal once again from my position.
The second thing I want to say goes out to my British friends - and that is 'cross all parties'.
My dear British friends, I understand Caroline. I understand your problems.
I can well understand that one country's energy security was temporarily prioritized over maintaining a limit on atmospheric pollution from aviation.
I fully understand that.
I am also the last one who would not give Her Majesty additional time if it were a question of building new coal-fired power plants.
We can talk about that.
The problem is, we have exactly not done that.
This conversation has never taken place during the last four months.
I would like to ask you to look at this issue in the second reading with an open mind and say let us discuss a compromise here.
For the irrational competitive and environmental policy that is not justified in my view, I will give the fundamental opposition against the minimum standards.
I believe that is the point at which a compromise can be reached, and I hope that we will also receive amendments in the second reading.
I do not believe that we should not seek a compromise at the first reading.
For this reason, this legislation is too complex.
I do not want to conclude this legislature as rapporteur and leave the next parliament with a立法 text that is inconsistent, illogical and contradictory.
Therefore, I would like to ask for your support for the compromises when we vote on it in one hour's time. Thank you very much.
The decisive question in all the economic programs that are currently being implemented across Europe is, of course, who will ultimately receive the money.
Will the banks be given more blank cheques, even though the state takeover would ultimately be much cheaper for taxpayers?
And should high-income groups and taxpayers be further relieved of taxes even though they have been subsidised by tax gifts throughout Europe for years?
The more money is spent on such purposes, the less appealing these programs will become, and the more likely it will be that the European economy slides down an extremely dangerous downward spiral.

The years-long policy of privatization, deregulation, liberalization – it is this very policy that has increasingly concentrated income among the top 10%, and it is this policy that is responsible for the current crisis we are facing today.
Who believes that he can overcome this crisis by continuing exactly the same policy with minor modifications - I think they have not understood anything at all.
The precise counterpart of this is necessary.
Instead of buying bad papers from banks, tax money should be used to clean schools, hospitals, and to rebuild the European economy environmentally.

In order for private companies to receive public funds, they must provide employment guarantees and, above all, acquire public ownership rights, so that the state and, above all, the general public can participate in future revenue streams.
The best economic program that there currently is would be a radical redistribution of income and wealth from the top down.
The hungry sector in Europe must be pushed back, instead of being further encouraged.
We need higher minimum wages and better social benefits in Europe.

We need taxes that ensure that millionaires and past financial market party beneficiaries also carry the immense losses that have arisen, and not just the large majority of citizens who have never benefited from the entire financial bubble.
I believe that social justice is also the most sensible economic policy today.
The only possibility to break through the prevailing crisis dynamics.
In January, political prisoners Mihail Chodorkovsky and Platon Lebedev were transferred from the city of Chita in Siberia to Moscow to face trial again on charges that were considered inadmissible.
The first public negotiation day was scheduled for March 31st.
The same day, the human rights consultations between the EU and Russia were supposed to take place.
These important talks have now been postponed indefinitely by the Russian side.
Russia demonstrates very clearly that whoever is lowered will be relegated to human rights.
The justice system will continue to be used not just for fairness, but also to exclude regime opponents, and the EU will be deceived by this.
Thank you very much, Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues. I am especially grateful to Mr Verheugen that he has also addressed the ban on animal experiments once again.

Hingewiesen hat, weil es mich daran erinnert, dass das jetzt die dritte Änderung der Kosmetikgesetzgebung ist, die ich begleiten durfte – die sechste Änderung, die siebte Änderung und jetzt die Veränderung zu einer Verordnung.
We have indeed succeeded in banning animal experiments.
We have achieved it, for example, consumers can find out how long a product is still valid by looking at a small package with an expiration date on it that says how long it is valid for.

I also say this to some addresses, especially to Mrs Rauter, who unfortunately could not be present at the beginning – labelling is never a warning sign. At no point in time should a product which is not safe be placed on the market, allowed to be sold.
Every product on this European market must be safe and unproblematic.
But labelling gives consumers the possibility to choose.
This is democracy, and this is their freedom of choice.
I believe that we have very good legislation.
I have attempted to make the procedure very transparent.
I have attempted, as Mrs. Kósász said, to bring together different opinions.

It is my intention to produce legislation that is beneficial for consumers and businesses in the European Union, for industry as it works with this legislation, and ultimately for all those who benefit from it.

In English, the German speech translates to: 'I have to say it again to Mr Schnellhart: Yes, DEO works differently for everyone, but the statement that it keeps you free from sweating will still be made.'
Therefore, it is important that the statements about my 'falte' (flaw) after one week in Strasbourg are somewhat realistic and reliable.
I would like to express my gratitude once again to the Commissioner, as well as to the Members of Parliament and my co-workers who did most of the work.
Thank you very much.
The report by Mr Nisticheu on the Green Paper and the future form of cohesion policy is certainly one of the most important of the last few years in the Committee on Regional Policy.
We support the basic concept of the Green Paper, as regards territorial cohesion, which concerns the polycentric development of the EU.
Overall, as well as sustainable development of the high seas areas with various features and species to ensure, and at the same time to preserve their diversity.
It is right that in the next planning period a more comprehensive system of gradual assistance for transitional regions should be introduced which will help to reduce the壁垒 of 75%.
The percentage of domestic product must be exceeded in order to create a clear status for these regions, thus providing more security for their development.
In the report by Mrs Grähe on obstacles in accessing structural funds, the most significant shortcomings are correctly listed that applicants face in applying for them.
In accordance with structural funds, e.g., excessive administrative burden, too many complex regulations, slow and cumbersome centralized administration in the Member States.
There will be many different recommendations made to the Commission on how to remove these obstacles.
I simply want to emphasize two such measures.
Project managers must keep project documentation for a period of ten years in order to make it available for controls that will also be carried out by the Commission.
Es ist besonders für kleinere Projekte übermäßiger bürokratischer Aufwand.
Correctly reduced to a period of three years. And secondly, the evaluation criteria of the EU Commission for innovative projects cause considerable problems.
Innovative projects should not be evaluated with the same criteria as other projects.
It is simply necessary that something different happen here.

When Europe takes money into its hands and especially when the Member States take a lot of money into their hands to help the automobile industry in its crisis situation, then it cannot just be about securing the stock and the status quo and preventing decline, but it must also be about a number of other issues.
The most important ones have been named.
The speech translates to: 'It is about finding jobs for people; they need to ensure that these jobs are long-term.'
For this reason, it is necessary that we promote new technologies, innovation, and above all sustainability in the transportation system more strongly than we have done so far.

Therefore, we should link all our measures with these goals so that we do not find ourselves accused in a few years' time of having failed to think about anything before. We should have thought about this many years ago, otherwise we will not be prepared for the next crisis.
Madam President, it would be nice if you could also grant me the half a minute that my fellow Green Member Mrs Breyer has just received.
The Commission has tabled a good proposal for updating the regulation on novel foods.

Unfortunately, some amendment attempts to supplement this proposal with provisions that are not consistent with the objectives of the regulation or even attempt to interfere with existing legal practices.
The obligation of food manufacturers to monitor novel foods with regard to health and animal welfare would certainly overwhelm traders.
And once again there is an attempt to undermine existing GVO laws by calling for a specific labelling of such novel foodstuffs obtained from animals fed genetically modified feed.
We have just heard it!
Generally speaking, everything that is affected by the GVO legislation should not be covered by the Novel Food Regulation.
I say this even though I myself, for example, had tabled an application to exclude certain new plant varieties from the definition of novel food.
But it cannot be that interested circles in this House misuse the novel food regulation for election campaign purposes.
It appears that the greens have also tabled an amendment on this issue, for which they have requested a separate vote.
Who, dear colleagues, do you want to provoke with this?
My group has also always been committed to consumers' right to know what is in foodstuffs.
So why should one not refer to the declaration of contents on a nano origin in the declaration?
And although Amendment 62 attempts somewhat vaguely to catch up with my report on food labelling, I have to tell you that I consider this novel food labelling to be fully compatible with my report.
I therefore recommend that my group support the aforementioned motions and I will refer to that part of the Novel Food Regulation in my report on food labelling.
It is possible because we have secured the first reading against the will of the greens.
But now it becomes clear to everyone how advantageous this partition was.
Klonen is animal cloning.
We are against it.
Despite this, foodstuffs must be included in this regulation, otherwise they will not be covered by it in any way. Thank you very much.
It's as simple as that.
Who does not want this man to lead the ceremonial opening sitting of the European Parliament should vote in favour of my motion for a change in the Rules of Procedure.

One thing is clear from the start: providing food aid to those in need, especially during these economically difficult times, should not be a topic for debate when we come to vote on our colleague Mr Scicchetti's report.
Therefore, I would also like to make it clear from the beginning that it was not easy to find a common line within our group.
Therefore, respected the personal decision of each group's colleague to deviate from our planned rejection of the report and not to agree.
Why cannot I agree with the outcome of the committee's vote in this form?
There are several reasons why this is not, but also really nothing at all, with help for those in need in the European Union in these economically difficult times.

In contrast, the amendments tabled by my colleague Mr Buzek on behalf of the EPP Group, which unfortunately were not accepted as duly tabled amendments, should serve to establish the existing system on a sound future basis.
The previous system was anachronistic from times of agricultural overproduction, which belongs to the glory of the past.
Thanks to successful decoupling, the intervention stocks have gradually decreased over recent years, so that today, up to 85% of foodstuffs must be purchased on the free market.
But it has fundamentally changed the character of the program and led to the loss of the agricultural dimension.
Since we are now dealing with a social program, we must create an appropriate legal basis for it.
Here we present the assessment of the Council's Military Service as an alternative to Article 37 of the EAGGF in respect of the common agricultural policy solely.
Article 308 ECT as a legal basis for this possibility. Otherwise, it would clearly be an infringement on the national competence of the Member States.

The value of the speech to the European Council yesterday morning was a premeditated insult, on which I myself no longer want to comment because I was the target of an insult.

Ladies and gentlemen, Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, Mr Gauzès, and shadow rapporteurs, I am pleased that we have taken this step forward, which is the first time that a sector of the European financial system has been placed under European direct supervision.
This is also a step towards a strong Europe in a single market with strong control over a sector that contributed to the crisis.
I would like to make one comment. Mr Vannucci, at this time, the selection processes for the new authorities and the personnel of these new authorities are only as good as the people involved.

I can only hope that when it comes to selecting personnel, expertise will truly be prioritized over ties to the finance industry they are supposed to regulate, over serving public interests clearly, and that we will not see national quotas again in the selection process that override these important criteria.
In addition, there is still much to be done in terms of credit rating agencies.

We still do not have proper transparency in the information on which credit rating agencies base their work, and there is excessive use of regulatory ratings in the financial world and in regulations governing the financial industry.
We have serious interests conflicts; we have a market power of three big providers and no obligation for reliable ratings.
Therefore, Mr. Commissioner, it is good that the consultation process is now underway, and we look forward to the results.
I think that civil society should also be involved in this consultation process, but then it must also be about making a bold proposal.
I look forward to your suggestions.
Be as courageous as you have been so far and let us jointly make laws next year that really solve the problems in the rating market which still exist at European level.
This is what we owe to our citizens.
The English translation of the provided German speech is: 'Which damage rating agencies can establish – that has shown the last few months since the beginning of this year.'
So there is an urgent need for action.
Therefore, I welcome - or in this regard, I also welcome - the directive, especially as ESMA has been entrusted with supervising and registering rating agencies.
I believe this is an important and good step forward.
However, numerous good and continuing suggestions have remained at the negotiation stage regarding the report.
I would like to emphasize this point once again.
The assignment of the ESMA therefore remains the only real and positive innovation.
Proposals for a public data basis for the creation of ratings have been dropped, as has every reference to the establishment of a public rating agency.
The subsequent and continuous supervision of ratings produced by supervisory authorities has also fallen under the table.
The Commission had suggested promoting unregulated ratings in order to overcome the onerous regulatory requirements for assessing financial market products. Nothing has been left from this either.
I hope that these aspects will be taken into account in the upcoming reports on this topic from Mr. Jean-Paul Grosjean and also from you, Mr. Barroso.

Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, distinguished Members of the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen. I would like to start by thanking those who worked on this report, especially Mr Bencsics.
I would like to draw your attention to two aspects and perhaps think about them a bit more carefully.
We agree that energy efficiency and saving energy is the solution, the easiest and most reasonable one.
The question is how we achieve this goal?
What has brought about the situation where we in parliament keep being confronted with new and higher percentage figures when it comes to people?
Have we really achieved more and moved forward more?
Or why and at which points has energy been saved with energy?
I learn that the industry which consumes much energy saves energy sparingly because it saves money and it is convenient for them.

I learn that people then, if they know this device consumes more energy or less energy, so if they see it and can decide for themselves whether it is advantageous for them, they will make a decision in favor of it.
The method may not be the right one for working with percentages, but we should proceed with the method by providing incentives.
The second question: The Commissioner has just vividly and clearly demonstrated how complicated the description of the term itself is – what exactly is it?
How differently does this vary in the Member States?
The colleague has just pointed out that the Member States have quite different situations economically and geographically speaking.
Is it correct to use one number, one binding figure, or should we not worry about it anymore?

I believe we have to solve something in energy policy. We should stop dwelling on past debates with simple numbers, binding targets, and attempts to impose some kind of miracle solution, because it is obvious that we have not achieved enough.
Let's try another approach, the differentiated approach that takes into account different situations and circumstances, but also achieves results.
It depends on the effects, not on our presence.
The regulation being discussed today has not received much attention in all committees for a long time.
At the end, but as the result was in sight, some people in this house woke up.
Some unfortunately did not appear for the debate, it would have been very interesting to hear their opinions as well.
As a former member of the convention, the spirit of the convention is still very clear in my memory.
Who has demanded quite clearly that the European Parliament must acquire certain rights in order to maintain its credibility within the institutions and towards citizens and taxpayers.
In that regard, what was given to us by the convent has still not been granted.
These were extremely difficult negotiations, mainly conducted by the Belgian Presidency with the Council, which made it possible to achieve some important progress.
I would like to recall what Mr Lehne has already said – it was the question of the constant possibility of monitoring whether the Commission has exceeded its powers.
Of course, there are some regulations that are not quite ideal, such as the international trade agreement, but still, I can explain the result to myself in agreement.
Thank you to the Belgian Presidency.
She really stuck her neck out for this, and our rapporteur, who negotiated with his heart and mind.
13th. I should like to make the following statement on behalf of our group. That is an amendment which my colleague Mr Goeran Fermer tabled in the Committee on Budgets on behalf of our group.

It is important that the EU deals with the problems of migration and asylum law.
The Commission has tabled its proposals.
There is currently no precise analysis on the implementation of existing legal regulations.
There are hardly any complete calculations and analyses for the new proposals.
I can confirm that the SVP unreservedly recognizes the right to asylum and the right to protection for those in need of protection.
The consideration of reality, however, unfortunately also leads us to the problem that the right to asylum is claimed for other reasons or even deliberately misused.
The right to asylum and subsidiary protection is not an instrument for mass immigration to the 27 Member States.
We must also ensure that organized human traffickers do not have any chance of profiting from our asylum law by exploiting people's fates to their billions.
Asylum procedures must be qualified and carefully conducted.
The translated text is: 'Followed people have to find protection in EU.'
Therefore, corresponding obligations from the Commission are envisaged in the new proposals.
I hold many of them in high regard, such as dolmetscher, regular health care, taking account of special protection needs.
I would like to mention points which I consider problematic.
The authorities in the Member States receive far too few opportunities to prevent abuse.
The possibility of accelerated procedures and border procedures should be limited by surcharge.

If an applicant massively violates his/ her co-responsibility obligations, there are hardly any sanctions possibilities; quite the contrary! If he/she illegally disappears, then the Member State should no longer be able to end its procedures negatively; if they re-emerge, then a broader range of procedural options should be available to them.
Even in cases of obvious lack of grounds, a accelerated procedure should be possible after the second instance.
It means considerable cost increases.
The free legal advice in the form of a lawyer is also an considerable cost increase for the states according to the current draft of the commission.
I simply request that the Commission consider the practical implications of its proposals in terms of financial implications and problems for Member State administration.
We want a high standard, but it must also be implementable, and in particular, it must not impose an impossible task on particularly burdened Member States.
Thank you very much for giving me the opportunity once again to speak briefly.
I have one big request to you, Mr Füle.
False assumptions lead to false cost estimates.
We do not have falling numbers in the area of asylum seekers at present; instead there are clearly rising numbers.
It has to do with visa facilitation, for example, to Serbia and Macedonia.
We are currently experiencing a massive increase in the abuse of asylum law as an attempt to enter the European Union.

If false assumptions are made, namely that by spreading out the first instance in more qualified reforms, costs in further instances could be saved automatically, it is automatically assumed that all Member States have a bad first instance.
This is not the case.
If standards are generally increased, then it will lead to cost increases as a consequence.
An increase in quality standards for everyone and also the complicated procedures. I am happy to discuss this in practical terms, but it leads to more costs in reality.
Please take the concerns of the countries seriously, because there are practical reports from the countries which partly exist and have also been given.
The Commission will be presented as having a successful competition policy in this report.
Unregulated competition can also contribute to increasing unemployment and widening the gap between the rich and the poor.
Unfettered competition is still prioritized over people's social needs in the European Union.
The credo of free markets cannot override the fact that they repeatedly fail to establish social justice permanently.
A couple of procedures concerning anti-trust and price fixing will not solve this problem.
A fair and at the same time socially just internal market can function only with strong and fair regulation.
More is urgently needed.
It is not acceptable, for example, to always give preference to private sector services over public sector services in order to promote private sector competition.
The report sets out guidelines for the Commission's future competition policy.
Much stronger consumer protection, the exclusion of public services from the competition rules, and the control of cartels – all this is urgently needed.
In addition, it would be necessary to include a treaty clause for a guaranteed social progress that at least stands on an equal footing with the competition rules in Europe.
It is a really important moment for us to remember the Holocaust of the Roma and Sinti people in this European Parliament for the first time.
Let me start with a farewell letter written by a fourteen-year-old boy named Robert Reinhard before his deportation from a German children's home to Auschwitz in 1943.
He said, 'I have found my parents again.'
We are on the transport to the concentration camp.
I have come so far inwardly that I can carry death on my shoulders.
Thank you once again for everything that you have shown me.
Hello again, in heaven.
Lass mich das sagen!

My dear colleagues, this young man came like five hundred thousand others from Sinti and Roma and did not go back. Although together with Jews, they were among the first victims of industrial mass killings, today, sixty-six years later, the full truth about this remains unspoken.
And also, the participation of the majority society is often tainted.
We need the whole truth about this chapter in history.
The Holocaust against the Roma and Sinti must be recognized as a crime against humanity so that this history does not repeat itself.
We must combat discrimination against these people with passion.
Racism and violence, such as those that occurred in Hungary last year, must be met with a united response, using civil courage.
Freedom, equality, and solidarity are not privileges enjoyed by individuals but are rights shared by all, because human and civil rights are inalienable.
Ladies and gentlemen, in my view, it is now about making the possibilities of the law really work.
In order to tap the full potential of a strong European financial supervisory system, we have doubts as to whether these possibilities can really be exploited institutionally.
We see deficiencies in the procedure. We have not yet received the list of candidates as an institution from the Commission, but only the final result.
It would be simple for us to send them now to the executive directors.

We have clearly identified a lack of gender equality in the appointment of posts, and there has been doubt in the process about whether the Member States will genuinely appoint these institutions in the European interest.
The further points in our paper legitimate a basic question to be asked.
But in addition, it goes beyond that, of course, and concerns the ownership of individuals, where each person must be judged individually according to their competencies.
There we have two big problems.

We have heard in the hearing that one of the candidates stated that it is about a European institution, but actually it is about a network of supervisory authorities, and also when asked about this during the hearing, he was not ready to correct himself.
We have not received any clear statements regarding whether you are prepared to make all lobby contacts with the finance industry transparent.
We have sent a letter to all three candidates, and the outcome of the vote depends on whether we receive clear and comprehensive answers.
Thank you, Mr President. We as the Social Democratic Group tabled the same motion.
However, I would like to recommend to Mr Mauro and the House that we be somewhat more precise.
It has to do with a huge inflow of capital.

Madam President, Commissioner, honourable Members of the European Parliament, I would like to express my strong appreciation for the outcome of the conciliation procedure.
With the implementation of the regulation, it will be possible to achieve a high standard of safety comparable to other modes of transport for all passengers, including those with limited mobility.

The English translation is: 
Firstly, a high level of consumer protection is achieved; secondly, a high standard of general consumer protection is ensured; thirdly, account is taken of the fact that it concerns an essentially small and medium-sized enterprise-dominated sector of trade.

Therefore, extreme subsidies that have made bus services almost impossible due to excessive demands were also removed from the table as well as requests where the majority of Member States would fall completely out of the scope of the regulation.
Bus services that generally benefit citizens must also provide high quality service to disabled people and those with limited mobility.
You should have a claim on help; in the interest of social integration, it should be free of charge.
Thank you, Madam President. I would like to wish everyone happiness, particularly Mr Canshian for his efforts in working out a compromise on this difficult file.
There were successes that have already been counted, but there were also disappointments, such as the scope of application and other pettinesses that have already been demonstrated.
With this compromise on bus transport, we have covered all transport modes with passenger rights.
The next necessary step is to create a common consistent and efficient framework program for all passengers.
Fair and clearly defined rights are of particular importance for the credibility of the EU among European citizens.
In order to be credible, it must also respect the consistency of rights for various modes of transport.
For passengers with reduced mobility, fundamentally different criteria apply than, for example, for regular passengers.
Therefore, it is particularly important when developing a framework programme not to set standards that are too low or weak but instead to maintain ambitious targets in the interests of citizens.

Ladies and gentlemen, we find ourselves in a major economic crisis. We have been talking about it for months now, and that is all very well, but as a rule, we discuss this in abstract terms and then nod our heads obediently as if nothing had happened.
I believe it lies in the fact that we in parliament also do not act specifically and honestly enough, but rather it is just a signature politics that takes place.
What are we actually doing to promote growth and stability?
We should also take responsibility for managing our finances more carefully and wisely.
Do we really have a critical examination as to whether we are making the right expenditure decisions or does everyone of us not have a new idea every day where we can still spend money?

If we do not have the strength to concentrate financial resources on future projects – that means disputes and disagreements and decisions – then it makes no sense to talk about innovation and research, but not to make funds available for them.
It is relatively unfair.
If we want to encourage the economy, then we must also make a policy that encourages the economy and not spend all day thinking about how we can disturb industry or the economy.
We conclude quickly, continue making decisions, and constantly demand new decisions that disturb the economy in its development.
Does anyone believe that the issue of binding energy efficiency targets, to give just one example, contributes to economic growth?
Do you really believe that our decisions on energy issues have boosted the economy?
Or have we disturbed them?
I would like us to have a bit more honest talk and then make fewer decisions, but perhaps those decisions that really move things forward.
It will be harder, it will be more difficult, there will also be disputes, but that is the essence of democracy.
The call for a financial transaction tax is not new; opponents of globalization have been advocating for such a tax for several years now.
Yet five years ago, hardly anyone would have believed that it could be achieved within a foreseeable time.
But this week it is on the agenda in the European Parliament together with a CO2 tax and Eurobonds - and I think that is a good thing.
The financial instruments proposed by Mrs. Polimata in her report can only be welcomed and supported, and I believe we will vote accordingly.
They are urgently needed instruments.
The consolidation of public budgets has so far focused solely on reducing expenditure.
The reduction in public expenditure primarily affects workers, retirees, and the poor, who rely on the welfare state.
The revenue side of public procurement has so far been completely ignored.
It is the second turning wheel that can be turned to consolidate public budgets.
The main cause of public debt crisis and the write-off of public debts should be involved appropriately.
For the consolidation of public budgets, an increase in tax revenue is simply indispensable.

In fact, high public debt is mainly a result of the state taking over private debts, namely the assumption of debts from private banks and the financing of the consequences of the financial crisis by the public sector.
The debt crisis is not caused by states alone.
Therefore, it is not only necessary but also politically expedient to invite the financial sector to pay its bills.
With the financial transaction tax, this sector would now finally be responsible for public debt as the main cause of its cancellation.
This is an important political signal that will emerge from this report if it is adopted as presented.
But at the same time, we also consider the Eurobonds to be a sensible and therefore necessary instrument.
They contribute more to reducing debts than all sanctions or more or less well-intentioned advice from the Council.

The complaints by some surplus countries that their interest rates have increased due to the Eurobank are not acceptable, as these same surplus countries also earn profits from their exports to deficit countries.

Whoever wants a social Europe, whoever wants the EU to hold together in the future, must basically agree to a transfer union in principle.
In conclusion, I would like to address the Commission and say that I hope it will finally present its proposals for a financial transaction tax, which has been called for over a year now. Thank you.
The rescue nets should protect EU Member States from insolvency.
They outsource people with brutal austerity programs and leave the perpetrators unharmed! Moreover, the Commission also interferes in national wage policies now.
Lieber Hahn, es ist absurd und es reizt die Tränen in die Augen, wenn man hier hört, diese formelle Argumentation. Das wäre alles gar nicht sozialpolitisch gemeint gewesen.
This position is totally unacceptable! Pay policy is not a matter for the EU. The Commission's policy stands in stark contrast to the idea of this European Union.
The European Union was never a project for downward competition on wages and social dumping.
There is talk of a reduction in wages that are considered excessively high.
In other words, wages should reflect market conditions.
Ladies and gentlemen, people who talk about color in this way have no idea what collective bargaining systems are.
You interfere with collective bargaining and lead the much-criticized autonomy of social partners and the social dialogue ad absurdum.
I want to make it clear that this parliament is called upon to ensure the preservation of autonomous collective bargaining policy, protect social dialogue and prevent further cuts in social security.
We need measures against counter-productive austerity policies and criminal actions.
Barroso, you are a clever man, but have you not answered my question?

Therefore, I will ask once again: when Mr Oettinger says that we have reason to suspect that certain systems, such as those on the Internet, may not survive our stress tests, does he mean that you are aware that these systems are so insecure that they do not comply with the criteria?
Why not do it today then?
In my opinion, this is a real danger.
I would like to ask both representatives from the Council and the Commission why they think they have to engage in this debate with talking points.

I believe that it does no good if it is not specifically stated that it is precisely in preparation for the Istanbul Conference that the Member States of the European Union and the European Union itself should act.
The development aid obligations must finally be fulfilled in full, and this cannot be tolerated in any way. Member States must increasingly withdraw from these obligations.
It is unacceptable that one billion people go hungry every day, and most of them live in the LDCs, which are the poorest countries in the world.

It is unacceptable that a large proportion of our development aid does not go towards supporting and building up agricultural structures, but has instead rapidly decreased over recent years, at a time when one billion people are suffering from hunger.
And then talking about it – we hope that the LDCs will become more shock-resistant, I find this somewhat unrealistic.
I urge you to speak about problems in a concrete and clear manner and to undertake specific commitments in order to genuinely help the LDCs.
In conjunction with the internal market, public procurement is an essential part of it.

Herr Barnier, wenn Sie sagen, dass Sie auch die soziale Integration fördern möchten in diesem Kontext, dann muss ich Sie fragen: Ich habe wenig davon gehört, über den Schutz vor sozialen Rechten, ich habe wenig davon gehört über den Schutz von Tarifverträgen.
This belongs to the basic rules that you, as you say, do not want to question yourself.

If you want to protect basic rules, you must ensure in future public contracts that essential social standards are protected, that wage dumping is prevented, and that there is no abuse of tendering procedures.
This belongs to modernized public procurement law.
Social fundamental rights must not be subordinate to economic freedoms and free competition anymore.
We want either a social Europe or we want long-term conflicts with people who turn away from this Europe because they do not see their interests being safeguarded.

In English, the speech translates to: 'Madam President, dear Commissioner Kroes, when it comes to radio frequencies, we are dealing with a valuable and limited resource that must be managed carefully, with a long-term perspective and taking into account overall societal aspects.'
Therefore, the 'Radio Spectrum Policy Programme' assumes special importance.
Frequencies must be used efficiently taking into consideration economic, social and cultural aspects.
To this end, all areas of technology must make full use of their technical possibilities in order to achieve maximum efficiency.

The basis of the frequency policy must be the telecoms package that was adopted last year, because it established that the EU and its Member States' frequency management must equally satisfy cultural, social, and economic interests.
This must especially be taken into account when harmonizing frequency use in the EU.
In this context, I would like to point out that the implementation of Digital Dividends has so far been carried out at varying speeds in the Member States.
The opening up of the ORF band, especially below 800 MHz, should therefore first be considered in the light of experience with the frequency bands in this range.
Many technical and financial issues have not yet been conclusively resolved.

The interference problem and the issue of cost-sharing for cultural institutions and local area corporations when it comes to technical upgrading, such as in the field of microphone technology, have not yet been satisfactorily resolved.
In the distribution of frequency bands, different interests must be weighed in a responsible manner.

The widespread supply with mobile broadband networks on the one hand is a basic requirement in the interests of European citizens; on the other hand, development in the field of public and private broadcasting as an important instrument for information and cultural diversity must also be taken into account.
We need to put the weaknesses in technological development, Europe's positioning in the field of digital information technology and cultural diversity right.
Ladies and Gentlemen, Mr Rehn, first of all I would like to say that you have described the situation as having worsened.
The eurozone, the share goes astray between countries that recover and countries that are weaker.

These 'unprecedented' commitments in the euro area.

The proposal for a European restructuring system has been delayed.
When does the Commission present this?
As the economic and monetary commissioner, how do you assess this delay?
Ist es wirklich schon so spät?
We have seen how we, as greens, have long said that measures against Greece, Portugal will not work unless the macroeconomic conditions in the eurozone improve.
We have still increasing absolutely high interest rates from a macroeconomic perspective for these countries.
We have increasing capital export and capital flight in some of these countries.
There is still a shortage of demand in several European partner countries, especially among the large eurozone countries.
And we have increasing resources and food prices - at least if you count the latest figures.

Finally, in my opinion, the measures have run counter to the spirit of the EU Treaty, hitting the weakest countries in Greece, Portugal and Spain especially hard, while the stronger and richer have not yet been called upon to share a part of the burden.
What measures do you take to ensure that wealthy individuals also contribute to the costs of this crisis?
Herr Präsident! Frau Glinge-Gönske ist eine Abgeordnete meiner Fraktion.
Man can be against Fidel Castro, man can be for Fidel Castro.

I think that Parliament must also reject this, especially from the representative of a party that stands out by its hatred and persecution of the Roma minority in Hungary, which it seeks to replicate throughout Europe.
If one person does not have the right to criticize Mrs. Kälin-Gönsz, then no one has that right.
The President. Madam President, dear colleagues, distinguished visitors, Europe's cultural diversity is an important good that must be preserved and further developed in the future.
To make this possible, we must not only place the challenges of the digital age in the field of information and knowledge society, but above all also in the area of culture and creativity.
Cultural diversity is not just an ideal value, but it also represents a significant economic factor.
In the EU, approximately five million people are employed in the cultural sector.
This corresponds to approximately two-thirds of total employment.
The cultural sector is a growth sector that develops faster than many other areas of business.

The development of information and communication technologies is driven by the content offered by the cultural sector just as much as it is influenced by the type and quality of content that has been transformed and developed through technology.
We need framework conditions for culture and creative industries that enable them to develop sustainably in the digital age.
We need a modern, accessible and secure system in which everyone can equally unfold.
The cultural and creative industry is a motor for Europe.
Therefore, we must also place an emphasis on this area in the field of school and vocational education.
We have to pass on cultural and creative competences to young people through lifelong learning opportunities.
We need to improve business skills among creators, not just in terms of entrepreneurship but also good media competence in relation to new technologies.
We need framework conditions under which culture can create conditions that secure their livelihoods.

Therefore, we have to focus intensively on issues such as copyright law, social security systems, and questions related to intellectual property, but also on open access to information and content in order to foster development.
To safeguard the creative and cultural industry in the digital environment and to preserve Europe's cultural diversity and heritage as an essential feature of the European Union.

Dear Mr President, dear Mr Kelam, dear colleagues from the Baltic countries, dear colleagues, today we are particularly mindful of the large-scale evacuations and mass deportations from the Baltic countries.
These expulsions belong to the darkest events in European history.
The past century has not been called an era of expulsions only because it was not, and not least, unjustly so.
We all shun the victims of these inhuman actions today.
We demand in this context a thorough investigation of Soviet history and, in particular, the crimes committed under Stalinism.

The English translation of the provided German speech is: 'Russia should not interpret today's events as a political attack but rather as support for the country in working out its own history, just like other European countries their history has been marked by sunny and shady sides.'
But just as we think about the victims from the Baltic states, let us also think about the Armenians who were expelled from Turkey at the beginning of the last century.
We refer to the so-called 'population exchange' between Turkey and Greece.
A special height point was reached by the deportations in Europe in the middle of the century by the Nazi regime and by the communist regime of the Soviet Union.
The displacement after World War II also left deep wounds, as did the displacements during the Yugoslav Wars.
We must not forget that many colonial regimes were characterized by expulsions.
We must seriously examine the various forms of displacement and their justifications.
The sentence translates as: 'This includes also the clarification of guilt and the punishment of perpetrators, as far as this is still possible, as in the current case in Bavaria for example.'

The decisive answer is European unification, particularly with and through the independent Baltic states, and a clear commitment to the continuation of the still unfinished European integration process.
This historic task is one that we owe not just to ourselves but also to the victims of many expulsions in Europe.
Many politicians from all over Europe, from East and West, have worked on this.
For example, think about the 'Tanzania Declaration' signed by Polish President Bronislaw Komorowski and German Federal President Christian Wulff.
We must grow wiser as we learn from the past, especially in relation to the first instances of persecution, such as that experienced by the Roma.

We must reject statements such as the one that suggests that Arab immigrants should be sent back to their boats in the Mediterranean. We must resist attempts by some to undo Europe's achievements in terms of borderless freedom and to revive narrow nationalism.

We should avoid falling into a trap of fear, especially when it comes to the victims of displacement and deportation. However, we must unreservedly commit ourselves to the continuation of European Union agreement as the only real guarantee against a future in which Europe could become a continent of states with multiple identities.

Numbers often tell more than big words do, and up until now, almost 2000 patents on plants and almost 200 patents on animals have been granted by the European Patent Office – and these were created with and also without the use of genetic technology.
Two outstanding examples I could mention are the granting of patents on genetically modified and by breeding modified cereals. This applies throughout the entire chain from seeds to plants.

This example shows, in my opinion, an enormous amount of patenting.
Second example: so-called 'longlife tomatoes' - do not confuse with their 'longlife oil', which you have in your diesel engines.

Patented is not the tomato itself but its genetic material, namely selected enzymes.

This shows with which trickery it is being done, and that although, as you said, Mr Commissioner, in the Biodiversity Patent Directive of 1998, in Article 4(2), it is clearly stated that 'Plant varieties and animal species A and B, in essentially biological processes for the breeding of plants or animals' are not patentable,
In our opinion, this definition needs to be made more precise. It needs to be explained more clearly.
Technological processes which are used to support conventional search should not lead to overall patentability.
We say specifically no patent on life.
We need a clear signal for more ethics and more honesty in dealing with cloning, once again against patentability on life throughout Europe.
Therefore, Commissioner, we demand a clear statement from the Commission that patents on plant material and genetic resources in Europe are prohibited and remain so.
Secondly, we demand a clear position on Article 4 of the Biopatent Directive – no patent on life.

The reform of the common preferential system was absolutely necessary.

However, the criteria are too vague, as has already been stated by the Committee on Development.
The Commission unfortunately relies solely on World Bank classifications.
In the past, Parliament has repeatedly been critical of GDP as the sole criterion.
The definition of countries with high middle incomes can refer to countries with GDP ranging from $4,000 to up to $12,000 per capita.
Therefore, it is a huge and far too large span, and it will never be fairly dealt with in reality.
We certainly do not find it questionable that countries such as Saudi Arabia and Kuwait should be allowed to continue to operate.
The reform was therefore good.
But these countries are high-income countries anyway.
Russia and China are countries with high middle incomes, whose exclusion from the GDP does not worry us in any way.
However, this category of countries also includes many poorer countries, such as Namibia and Ecuador.
The previous Commission at least also included the verifiability criterion, which means countries that export little or only very few goods.
This will prevent countries that are less dependent on exports and very vulnerable from being overrated.
Why then has the Commission excluded this criterion?

Countries such as the Dominican Republic, the French Polynesian Islands, Gabon, and Botswana will therefore fall away, although their economies under the criterion of comparability fall within the category of developing countries.
Why has the Commission not continued with the old criteria, which were already inadequate?
There is a suspicion that the Commission is forcing poorer countries into unfavorable free trade agreements with them.
The preference system is an instrument for development promotion and cannot be replaced by pure trade instruments under which the development path of a country or region plays no role at all.
Hopefully, it will still be possible for Members in plenary to support our amendment which takes verifiability as a criterion.
The new regulation will also lead to the fragmentation of trading regions.
Neighboring countries in the customs union will have to follow different rules when exporting to the EU.
This has nothing to do with our aim of regional integration.
The commission should give more consideration to development regions instead of individual countries.
Also, we Greens have tabled an amendment which I hope will receive a lot of support.
It is also problematic when countries that have benefited from the APP yesterday should suddenly be removed from the program tomorrow.

Thank you Mr President, Baroness Ashton. I was also a member of the European Parliament election observation mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo and I could see with how much hope and expectation people stood at the polling stations waiting to cast their vote.

In the east of the country, violent clashes between government troops and so-called rebels have flared up again, and it is unclear whether third countries such as Rwanda will intervene.
In every case, it is the civilian population that has been suffering for decades and can no longer live in peace and security.
The wealth of the country is being drained away through corruption, and Congo remains one of the last countries in international assessments.

The international community, especially the European Union with its possibilities, must increase pressure on the President of the Republic of Congo to allow genuine democracy in his country. He has the opportunity to do so at the next regional elections.

In addition, it is necessary to establish that the Congolese army is not also terrorizing the civilian population but is instead finally capturing internationally sought-after criminals against humanity such as Bosco and Kagga, and bringing them before a court.
Finally, all states should commit themselves not to deliver any more weapons into Congo.
Without external pressure, human suffering and poverty in this country will not end.

Thank you very much, Mr President, Commissioner Barnier, distinguished Members of the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen.
