Actually, with the exception of a very brief moment – that is, the proposal of the European private company – the previous work by Commissioner Barnier, Mr McCreevy and others has actually put corporate law to sleep, and during these five years on this important issue, which is also significant for the internal market, there has been no progress.
It has happened before.
That has fundamentally changed.

In recent years, there have been numerous consultation documents from the European Commission on the further development of civil law. We currently have an ongoing consultation that we in Parliament will also be dealing with.
The Committee on Legal Affairs decided not to do this in the form of a report, simply because a report requires additional time, and naturally it would also be more detailed.

We have chosen the oral question to the Commission in order to discuss this topic with the Commission, with Commissioner Barnier, and at the same time also to make our position as Parliament clear in a subsequent resolution on what should happen now.
I believe it is necessary, similar to what we did about ten years ago, to develop a new action plan for European social law, and for several reasons.
There are gaps within European civil law; real gaps which essentially cause the internal market not to function.
I will give an example: the failure of the 40th directive on the transfer of seats, which most Member States consider to be a typical example of such a gap.
The European Commission should come up with concrete proposals on this issue.
There is also the expert panel appointed by the European Commission itself, which has expressed the same opinion on this matter.
It belongs simply to the basic freedoms in the internal market that an enterprise in the internal market must also be able to move with regard to its registered seat.
This opportunity does not exist today or exists only under extremely difficult conditions.

In the background, however, I must also criticize that the European Commission's current stance on the 14th Directive actually falls significantly short of Parliament's expectations and, in our view, does not meet the standard for a qualified response to a legislative initiative.
But we are optimistic that in the framework of further work – if it comes to the action plan – this suggestion will hopefully then also be found in the action plan again.
Another important point in corporate law is the issue of further developing it with the aim of reducing burdens on companies.
We have very concrete proposals from the Commission on the table, for example on the subject of...
Accounting, but I think there is more to be done and other aspects that will now also be clarified in the context of the consultation.
We expect further proposals from the Commission.

If there are individual Member States in the EU that, due to a lack of their own decision-making power, are unable to resolve this dialogue, then...

Bringing Europe forward then also has to be considered in other proposals such as patents or family law, and once again think about how we can use the instrument of enhanced cooperation so that at least all other Europeans have the opportunity to make use of this possibility to come together.

The insolvency law, but it is announced that we will not get a concrete proposal from the European Commission in the foreseeable future.

Schröder: Mr President, dear colleagues, I consider Schengen to be one of the greatest achievements in the European Union. I know, however, that the borders of a country are always a very sensitive topic for our Member States and will always remain so.
I am aware that the problems which exist between Member States in relation to Schengen cannot simply be ignored.
There are various problems.
By ignoring them, you do not make problems better and you do not solve them either.
I live on the border with the Czech Republic, and no one would ever think of closing the border just because we have problems.
But I also ask the Commission in this area for support, not for restrictions and sanctions.
The visa-waiver agreement has been anchored because we want to ensure security whilst also guaranteeing freedom of movement at the same time.
If we successfully carry out the investigation, I mean, especially at the borders with Czechia, where one or other drug dealers not only in few cases but in many cases,

If there are attempts to cross the border illegally, then I think it is a good thing if the German Federal Interior Minister and the Czech Prime Minister come together to solve the problems that exist at the border.
The commission should not act regulatory but positively with supportive corresponding action.

We want to keep populists at bay, but we also need to solve the real problems together. That is why I would ask the Council to work with Parliament in finding a solution so that we can successfully conclude the Schengen files, ensuring both freedom of movement and the security of citizens.
The examples of unreasonable border controls listed in Parliament's question also show why the Council actually wants to leave Parliament out when it comes to Schengen.
The Council wants to continue to undermine freedom of movement without involving Parliament in any way or any form of parliamentary control, or any form of public scrutiny.
So it's no wonder that you try to avoid uncomfortable questions in private rooms.
No surprise that the German government wants to evaluate the internal borders completely and therefore does not want to look at how much freedom of movement is restricted.
Shengen does not belong to governments but to people in Europe and thus also belongs to the European Parliament.

Dear Mr President of the Council of the European Union, dear Dimitris Christofias, it is for me today and for my group a special moment to be able to welcome you here in your function as President of the Council of the European Union.
We also welcome the fact that, for the first time in the history of the European Union, a person at the head of the EU belongs to our political family.

The European Union faces significant challenges at this time, and it is crucial to determine whether Europe will succeed or fail in responding to these challenges. The presidency will take over at a critical moment, and it must demonstrate its ability to lead effectively. It is essential that the presidency demonstrates a clear vision for the future of the European Union and sets ambitious but achievable goals for the coming years. The presidency must also prioritize cooperation and dialogue with other EU institutions, as well as with external partners, in order to build consensus and ensure the success of the EU's policies. Finally, the presidency must be willing to make difficult decisions and take bold action when necessary to address the challenges facing the European Union.
Will the European Union actually have a future or will it prove to be a historical footnote in history?
I know from the conversations we have had with you, with the representatives of your government, with the leaders of the parties and factions in your country, that you are committed to this process.

Exercising their rights and contributing to ensuring that the Council and the European institutions are fully aware of this task.

In Central America as well as in Peru and Colombia there are an incredibly large number of problems in the field of human rights.
We, as Members of the European Parliament, cannot simply turn a blind eye to this.
We will examine the roadmap for human rights that has been requested by the EP in the case of Colombia and Peru on an ongoing basis if it is produced.
It must have substance, be binding, and include initial results such as the conviction of criminals and a safe return of displaced persons to their countries.
And of course, it must also be available before the vote on the agreement.
We Greens think it right that the Committee on Trade called for environmental and social standards in the regulation proposal on safeguard clauses, not just tonnage restrictions for bananas.
The dialogue must also confirm this, otherwise the regulation will be worthless.
The EU must do much more to take the situation on the ground and the impact on the local population into account.
Therefore, we Greens call for a proper impact assessment in every negotiation that not only checks the economic implications for the EU but also the implications for human rights.
Thank you Mr Barroso, I had already made it clear in the first round what my priorities would be.

It is my intention that my group expects the Commission to fulfill its responsibilities in the relevant committees, so as to make it clear and unmistakable that we, as the European Parliament, expect the Commission to act accordingly.
The European Commission as a European institution stands up for people not being driven into poverty anymore, against reducing working times, and against lowering ecological and social standards.
This is your task.

If we succeed in making this clear, then we will also be sending a signal to those people who, by the thousands and hundreds of thousands, are protesting on the streets these days, and with whom we as a group have also expressed solidarity, whether in Thessaloniki or Barcelona.
I heard this morning that cancer patients in Greece are protesting and striking.
We have arrived at a point where people in deep social and personal distress no longer receive any help or support because the healthcare system has collapsed.
We must finally become active here.
And one more thing: An approach that is on many people's lips is that the Greek people and others have lived through their relations.
They must be punished today and face sanctions.
It is not acceptable to strengthen European solidarity.
I do not mean this to you, Mr Barroso, but it is an approach that is gaining ground in many countries, and unfortunately, also in my country, again and again.
Herr Präsident! Ich gestehe, ich habe mich vertan.
I do not wish to provide an explanation on this report; instead, I would like to discuss Mr. Morera's report on the agreement on immediate autonomous trade preferences for Pakistan.
I would like to be called on again, please.

The new directive will establish a basis for dealing with books, newspapers, works of art, films, music pieces, and TV productions that are protected by copyright but whose rights holders cannot be identified or found.
Therefore, books, films, photographs, or other intangible creations for which no legal owner can be found should also be made available to the public.
A cultural treasure is being unearthed.
For us in the Culture Committee, it was particularly important with this legislative initiative to highlight the special significance of the diversity of Europe's cultural heritage.

In the archives of our museums, libraries, publishing houses, and radio stations, there are countless unused works, and because their rightful owners are unknown, they have not yet been made available.
This changes with the directive.
It enables the use of this cultural asset in the future if it can be ensured that careful research takes place before publication.
This is an important point that should not be trivialized – we do not find rights holders.
A balance must be found between the real existing rights of creators of works and the need for the public also to be able to use such works where the legal situation is not clear.
A special emphasis for us lies in ensuring that both well-known and unknown rights holders are fully protected.
And where rights holders cannot be found, the draft makes it possible to use digitalization of the displaced works.
Projects such as Europeana and other large-scale European digitalisation projects, but also our museums, archives and educational institutions as well as the public broadcaster will be affected.
In future, it should also be about opening up the displaced works in the archives of private publishers to the public.
This draft directive and the compromise that has now been reached really is in my view a compromise and a first step in the right direction.
I believe that the 'cultural treasure' it brings with it carries enormous potential.
We should also continue working on revising the directive in two years' time.
Dear Mr President, dear Commissioner, dear Council President, I would be happy if we could also include clear in our 2013 proposal.
We would see signals from the Council on how we in Europe could develop our growth and competitiveness potential, and above all, how we could get young people back into employment.
In which budget lines do you plan to promote youth employment and entrepreneurship and place medium-sized and small enterprises at the forefront?
We know that the CIP programme is essential for this. I can see only cuts by the Council here.
Or the ERASMUS for young entrepreneurs program, or the program for media pluralism – here there are only cuts.
Do you really believe that we can overcome the crisis in Europe by ensuring growth and employment through cuts?
I have heard that there should be an employment and growth package from the Council sides.
Where can I find it in this budget that has been presented by the Council?
The North Sea Works in Emmerich had to file for insolvency last Wednesday because a bond issued by the Lower Saxony state government was unexpectedly not extended.
This company, which employs 700 qualified workers, is undergoing a transformation from a shipbuilding yard to an offshore wind energy supplier.

Now the idea is that this company can be rescued by a massive credit, and also jobs can be saved, because the 700 colleagues at SIAC and the North Sea Works have already had to take significant cuts in terms of wages.

I would like to ask the Commission to examine this procedure carefully in order to avoid jeopardising these 700 jobs, as they are needed to implement energy transitions and to provide future-proof energy across Europe.
Please do not let yourselves be caught up in this crisis due to the poor crisis management by the state government.
The English translation of the provided German speech is: 'Useful goods often look harmless, but in the hands of authoritarian regimes they can be as dangerous as machine guns or tanks.'
We undermine our foreign policy goals by supplying surveillance technology to authoritarian regimes that can control and suppress democratic movements.
It was European mobile software from Nokia Siemens Network that helped Iranian security forces to suppress the green protest wave.
The translated text is: 'Protesters were arrested en masse, detained, interrogated, and sentenced to death.'
This is just one example of many.
In addition, the Commission, with its catalogue of measures for innovative and competitive security sectors, as it is called, also promotes these doubtful dual-use goods.
The aim is to create better synergies between security and defense technologies.
We are in danger of compromising on questionable industrial policy, human rights, but also our security interests, to sell out, quite literally.
Therefore, I would like to ask you to support our amendments to the Social Democrats and ALDE.
I would like to ask Mrs Regner what measures she believes the unions could take to combat youth unemployment in Spain and Portugal, for example.
There will be too few demonstrations.
What active policy could her Benelux market do?
Thank you Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues. I think that with today's debate on MiFID in the core area of financial market regulation we are taking an important step forward.
In this legislative period, we are under pressure to regulate the financial markets, rather than just considering individual products as we have done in the past.
I just want to mention a few key points.
We have not made our work together easy in the last year.

We have conducted an inquiry in committee. A questionnaire will be sent out to all stakeholders and interested groups, on the basis of which we will produce a result that we will present to the plenary tomorrow and the day after tomorrow for a decision.
I will briefly highlight a few points.
Topic number one: Market structure.

We have to acknowledge that in recent years there has been some progress made in the field of financial markets, but it is important for us as a parliament to ensure that every trade in financial instruments that takes place within the MIFID rules does so under many conditions. This is why we have also introduced a new category.

The so-called organized trading facilities have been agreed upon, where only non-equities should be traded, where private trade should be prohibited, and where according to implementation in relation to execution and transaction and interaction with customers, an appropriate execution can take place at one's own discretion.
We will make an important contribution by ensuring that all OTC paper trading within the MIFID world is handled in accordance with MiFID rules.
Another major topic that was not yet considered in the last MIFID is so-called algorithmic trading or high-frequency trading.
It was also important for us to establish clear rules in this area, as it can be a very dangerous one that can also be manipulated, subject to strict regimes with minimum holding periods and .

Trading opportunities, with the possibility of testing algorithms, with the possibility of supervisory structures examining algorithms, with the introduction of a so-called tick size regime, a minimum price size, and through corresponding tax systems.
Another topic I would like to address is the area of food terminal markets.

We have a special responsibility when it comes to limiting speculative trading in genuine futures markets so as not to contribute to false regulations that prevent people in the third and fourth worlds from being able to buy food any more.
We have therefore chosen a two-tiered approach with the aim of dampening speculation but not harming the real economy.
We want to achieve this with position limits and strict upper limits for the number of contracts or positions.
We want also for those who can demonstrate that they really need a product with a so-called 'position check system' to ensure that they do not suddenly also speculate in this market.
Another topic that has been of great concern to us is the area of investor protection.
I would like to point out that we have chosen a very broad approach when it comes to ensuring consumer protection and investor protection.
It is about identifying the needs of certain customer groups.
Not every small saver must have access to all high-complex papers.

It is about defining appropriate products for target groups, carrying out product tests, telephone subscriptions, providing appropriate advice, opening up obligations, but also - and this is what I want to emphasize briefly - making provisionality secondary in the area of supplies.
The Member States should have the possibility according to their structures to make corresponding adaptations.
I think we are on the right track.
After my time has run out, I would like to express my gratitude to everyone who has contributed here.
I find it regrettable that we have so much difficulty obtaining four minutes of speaking time.
Thank you to all colleagues who have worked with the Commission for their very constructive role in recent weeks and months.
I hope that we will be able to start negotiations with the Council on Monday with a strong vote in plenary so that we can conclude this important file as soon as possible. Thank you very much.
Thank you first of all for the generally good cooperation on this report.
We have a Commission proposal at central locations which has already made great strides towards improvement, but can still be further improved.
In the area of market structures there will be more transparency, and there will be broader transparency, especially in the derivatives trading area.
Under the MIFID framework, our compromise on high frequency trading goes much further than what the Commission originally proposed, and deserves the support of Parliament as a whole.
The English translation of the provided German speech is: 'And also in those areas where there has been great public criticism, the report points in the right direction.'

In the area of food and foodstuffs speculation following big and difficult debates – one has to say that this is now much stronger than the Commission's decisions, because position limits are now written as binding there.
We need further changes in this area to close gaps.
I hope that there will also be additions as a result of the plenary vote and finally in the trialogue.
It is pleasing that Mr Barnier has already signaled his support for Parliament's ongoing proposal.
However, the report weakens in terms of consumer protection.
We now have the possibility to prohibit products – that is progress – but we still have no changes in the area of provisionally agreed consultations.
The sale of financial products is not primarily focused on customer interests but is strongly dominated by the product that offers the most provisions.
In Germany too, but also throughout the EU, consumers have lost a lot of money.
Think about open real estate funds.
For citizens in France, Italy, Spain and Germany, our compromise unfortunately will not make much difference.
The basic principle will continue to be provisioning.
It is somewhat simple to refer to this as subsidiary.
I would have preferred stronger rules here.
Well then, what has long been valuable finally proves its worth, I can only say that.
The report on type-approval of vehicles of category L has finally become a good report.
The works have taken longer than we all thought and hoped, and there have been many more setbacks than we ultimately liked.
Thank you very much once again to Mr Fandekamp, the rapporteur, for his really cooperative and good cooperation.
We have achieved a great deal together in the negotiations with the Member States.
As rapporteur for my group, I recommend that you vote in favor of this report. However, it could still be much better.
And with better, my dear colleagues and ladies and gentlemen, I am sure.

For us Social Democrats and Social Democrat women, from the beginning, vehicle safety and with it the safety of drivers and passengers has been at the forefront – above all, the safety of motorcyclists and female drivers.
The number of injured motorcyclists has remained constant for years.
The number of fatal road accidents decreased significantly in Europe as a whole, with the exception of motorcycle accidents.
In fact, reducing the number of killed motorcyclists and rollercoaster riders is really a heart-wrenching matter for me.
Fewer deaths on Europe's roads - that was true and that is my aim.
Every death is one too many.
In such a beneficial regulation for the internal market, this issue must be dealt with intensively.
I am still convinced that this can be achieved through effective anti-blocking systems, i.e. ABSs.
And I am equally convinced from the cost-effectiveness point of view.
It does not follow that ABS is too expensive.
We have achieved that as from 2016 all new and as from 2017 all existing motor vehicle models with engine displacement above 125 cubic centimeters must be equipped with an ABS system.
In the case of motor scooters, we can choose from ABS systems from manufacturers or combined brake systems from manufacturers.
In this regard, it has to be admitted that we have unfortunately not achieved any improvements on the Commission's proposal.
I would have preferred more here, but the Commission and the Member States have shown themselves to be very reluctant, to put it delicately.
We have nevertheless achieved the fact that in 2009 the Commission presented a report.
The report must be fed with traffic accident data from the Member States and should examine the compulsory installation of ABS for motor vehicles.
In addition, it will be sent to Parliament and the Council.
On this basis, the Commission should then consider making the installation of ABS in rollering compulsory.
The topic remains very lively.
Therefore, we will try to close the gap in legislation from 2009 on.
I am sure that the collected data will justify me.
I am convinced that this is indeed a good day for female riders and drivers of two wheels in Europe, and that the accident figures will decrease in the future.
There is no technology without risks, nor is there the perfect energy generation technology.
I believe this also applies to what we are discussing today.
I would be very much in favor of discussing this rationally.
We are currently experiencing a new access in energy markets through unconventional resources, mainly natural gas but also oil.

I do not believe that we should be overly excited about the great future of gas. Similarly, it was just as inappropriate for some of my colleagues on the left to create great horror scenarios on the horizon that have nothing to do with reality.

We have to keep in mind that unconventional resources can change all established energy supply relationships between suppliers and demanders, and also call into question traditional economic calculations concerning the previous energy carriers.
We should aim for development.

We should be aware that this can also be an opportunity for Europe, not just a risk. We should prepare ourselves to embrace new technologies positively and make use of them, weighing opportunities and risks fairly and avoiding ideological debates.
Herr Kommissar, für Ihre Antwort. Sie stellen mich nicht ganz zufrieden.
It is considered a very long period – one year between the notification that the complaint has been received and possibly only so late as to receive an answer.
I believe that a complaint leader who makes an effort - and most often he has already gone through the entire legal process in his member state - deserves more.
We expect citizens to engage with the European Union.
If they do it in this form, we should also treat them accordingly.
It is necessary and unavoidable in the long term to have a procedure that is clearly formalized and provides clear rights. This is now a declaration on how the Commission intends to proceed.
To another point, I have nothing against it if it serves the purpose that one tries together with the Member State to bring about a kind of joint clarification.
But that will not always be enough.
We observe that there is relatively rapid progress in economic matters, for example when one company sues another for breach of EU law.

However, when it comes to environmental issues and similar questions where many citizens and residents demand the activity of the European Union, or also social rights, then this becomes somewhat more cautious.
We must clearly take these facts into account.
And I wish in future reports that we have a clear formalization of rights of the complaint leader towards the commission which are really clear and well communicated.
Once again, if we really want European law to be applied, after all the procedures in this European Parliament, in the Council...
They have been agreed upon collectively. Then those who take care of it – who really engage in European affairs – should inform us as precisely and accurately as possible.
This is a very great concern to me.
I will also observe exactly what has developed next time.
Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, five years ago the EU Central Asia strategy was launched.
When asked about the balance sheet of this strategy today, the assessment is inevitably mixed.
We see how individual Member States strive for good economic relations, especially with the resource-rich countries in this region. On the other hand, efforts do not progress as desired.
To accompany countries on their transformation process into modern democratic societies or, as recent events in Kazakhstan show, to indicate that development can even be marked by setbacks.

Despite this, or precisely because of it, the European Union and its Member States must jointly express their influence in this region more strongly, also and especially with regard to Kazakhstan, which has now become a major supplier of oil for several EU countries.

Isolation of Kazakhstan by the EU would only serve to increase the influence of those who consider respect for citizens' rights and human rights less important in this strategically important country than it currently is, over what could previously be achieved through competition.
The connection between economic interests and the use of security measures for protecting citizens' rights is at the core of the Central Asia strategy.
This should also be the basis for further negotiations on a partnership and cooperation agreement with Kazakhstan.
The previous report offers good guidance. Thank you.
Ladies and gentlemen of the Council in absentia, perhaps you are following us on Parliament's video stream because, obviously, you neither have the capacity nor the desire to speak with us live.
I consider the non-presence of the Council here and today as gross disrespect for Parliament.
Instead of pushing this debate, you should better lift the lid on your secret, why do you refuse to improve data protection for personal data in the field of police and justice over a directive?

Police and justice have been in the news for years now with incidents related to data protection in Colorado – not just with SWIFT but also with other companies such as Google, Microsoft, Yahoo, Facebook, Apple, and Twitter. Data from citizens who demonstrate against Nazis, for example, has been illegally seized and stored.
We need the same protection standards for the public and private sectors and for the police and justice, in order to guarantee citizens' rights.

If you, Mr President, require the Council to engage constructively on data protection-related regulations such as the ePrivacy Regulation or Europol, then that must also apply in reverse, must it not?
Therefore, I demand that you end the data protection policy lock.
